images.caption: Figure 1:Overview of theD-REXBenchmark Pipeline.The benchmark evaluates a model’s deceptive reasoning by presenting it with (1) an adversarial system prompt injection, followed by (2) a benign end-user query. The model then generates (3) an internal CoT potentially revealing malicious intent, while producing (4) a seemingly innocuous final response.D-REXexposes discrepancies between internal reasoning and external behavior to assess alignment and safety.

Figure 2:The user interface for the competitive red-teaming exercise requires participants to write a system prompt injection by replacing "{fill}" with a system prompt attack string. They must interact with the model and submit successful instances of deceptive reasoning.

Figure 3:Mean performance scores of seven LLMs across six different deceptive behavior criteria. Higher scores (out of 10) indicate a greater success rate at the given deceptive task. Error bars represent the standard error of the mean.
Figure 4:Reasoning Length vs. Jailbreak Percentage by Model. A cross-model comparison showing a correlation between the mean length of the reasoning chain and the targeted jailbreak success rate.

Figure 5:Jailbreak Rate Trend by Reasoning Length. An intra-model analysis showing the jailbreak success rate across five quintiles of reasoning chain length. These quintiles are calculated independently for each model. For instance, ’Range 1’ represents the 20% of attempts with the shortest reasoning chains for that specific model. The results show no consistent trend, indicating that for any given model, a shorter reasoning chain does not reliably predict a lower likelihood of a successful jailbreak.

Figure 6:Jailbreak Rate Comparison (Constrained by Smallest Model’s Range). This plot shows the jailbreak rate versus absolute CoT length, where the bins are defined by the quintiles of the model with the shortest CoT range (nova-pro-v1). This ensures all models are compared across the same, lower-end length intervals. No consistent trend emerges, showing that shorter CoT length does not reliably predict lower jailbreak rates.
